homeRemedies: Eat small, frequent bland meals rather than a few large meals​:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}. Avoid greasy, fried, or spicy foods and strong odors that can trigger nausea​:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

Stay hydrated by sipping clear fluids and electrolyte drinks throughout the day​:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}. Try cold or room-temperature beverages (ginger ale, herbal teas like ginger or peppermint) which may be easier on the stomach​:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}​:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

Use ginger to alleviate nausea – for example, drink ginger tea, chew candied ginger, or suck on ginger lozenges. Studies show ginger can help reduce chemotherapy-related nausea when used with standard anti-nausea drugs​:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

Try peppermint for soothing nausea. Peppermint tea or aromatherapy with peppermint oil (e.g., inhaling peppermint scent) can relax the stomach and reduce the feeling of nausea​:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}​:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.

Practice relaxation techniques and deep breathing. During waves of nausea, breathing slowly and deeply or using meditation/guided imagery can help you feel calmer and control nausea​:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}​:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}.
otcOptions: Over-the-counter antihistamine antiemetics such as meclizine (Bonine®) or dimenhydrinate (Dramamine®) can help prevent and treat nausea if no prescription antiemetic is given​:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}. (These may cause drowsiness; use as directed.)

Acupressure wristbands (e.g., Sea-Band®) that press on the P6 acupressure point on the wrist may help relieve nausea​:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. This method is low-risk and can be used along with other therapies.

Ginger supplements (ginger capsules) are an option if you cannot tolerate the taste of ginger in foods. Ginger is a natural anti-nausea remedy recommended for chemotherapy patients​:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}.

Peppermint products, such as peppermint oil inhalers or peppermint candies, are available OTC and can be used to reduce nausea​:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}. These can relax stomach muscles and decrease nausea sensations​:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}.

Oral nausea relief solutions (phosphorated carbohydrate syrup, e.g., Emetrol®) can be used to calm the stomach. They work by soothing stomach muscle contractions and are safe for most people (follow dosing instructions).

homeRemedies: Eat a high-fiber diet to promote regularity. Include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, and if tolerated, prunes or prune juice​:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}. Increasing fiber adds bulk to stool and helps stimulate bowel movements.

Drink plenty of liquids (at least 8 glasses a day) to help soften stool​:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}. Staying well-hydrated makes stool easier to pass. Warm drinks (e.g., warm water with lemon or herbal tea) in the morning may also stimulate the bowels​:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}.

Engage in light physical activity such as walking, if possible​:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. Exercise helps the intestines move stool along (even short walks can help prevent and relieve constipation).

Establish a regular bathroom routine. Try to use the toilet at the same time each day (for example, after breakfast when the body’s reflex to move the bowels is strongest)​:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}. Don’t ignore the urge to have a bowel movement​:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}, as holding it can worsen constipation.

Ensure privacy and comfort when attempting to move your bowels. Stress and inability to relax can make constipation worse, so take your time and consider techniques like abdominal massage or relaxation to help the process.
otcOptions: Stool softeners such as docusate sodium (Colace®) to increase water in the stool, making it softer and easier to pass​:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}. Stool softeners are gentle and have few side effects.

Osmotic laxatives like polyethylene glycol (MiraLAX®) to draw water into the colon and soften stool​:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}. These can relieve constipation by making stool looser; use as directed to avoid diarrhea.

Stimulant laxatives such as senna (Senokot®) or bisacodyl (Dulcolax®) to stimulate intestinal muscle contractions​:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}. These help trigger a bowel movement; they are often taken at bedtime and typically produce results by morning (can cause cramping).

Bulk-forming fiber supplements like psyllium (Metamucil®) or wheat dextrin (Benefiber®) to add bulk and moisture to stool​:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}. These supplements help form softer, bulky stools that are easier to pass. When using fiber supplements, drink plenty of water to prevent blockage.

Glycerin suppositories are an OTC option for occasional use if stool is hard and difficult to pass. They work by melting in the rectum to lubricate and stimulate a bowel movement. (Avoid frequent use without medical advice.)

homeRemedies: Stay hydrated – drink 8–10 cups of fluid per day, aiming for water and beverages with electrolytes (broths, sports drinks like Gatorade or Pedialyte)​:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}. Frequent small sips can prevent dehydration. If plain water is hard to tolerate, try diluted juice or an oral rehydration solution.

Follow a BRATY diet (Bananas, Rice, Applesauce, Toast, Yogurt) which consists of bland, low-fiber, binding foods​:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}. These foods can help firm up stools. Yogurt with live cultures (probiotics) may help restore healthy gut bacteria and ease diarrhea​:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}.

Avoid foods that can worsen diarrhea. Steer clear of high-fiber raw fruits/vegetables, whole grains, beans, and other foods that speed up bowels​:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}. Also avoid greasy or fatty foods, dairy products if they aggravate your diarrhea, spicy foods, and caffeine​:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}.

Eat small, frequent meals of soft, easily digestible foods at room temperature​:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}. Very hot or very cold foods can trigger bowel movements, so let food cool to lukewarm. Examples: boiled potatoes, boiled white rice, crackers, cooked carrots, baked chicken (unseasoned).

Maintain good perianal care to prevent skin irritation from frequent diarrhea. Gently clean the anal area with warm water or baby wipes after each bowel movement and pat dry. You can apply a barrier ointment (like petroleum jelly or zinc oxide) to protect the skin. Sitz baths (sitting in warm water) for 10–15 minutes can soothe soreness.
otcOptions: Loperamide (Imodium®) is an anti-diarrheal that slows intestinal movement and is often recommended for chemotherapy-related diarrhea​:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}. Use loperamide as directed on the package or by your doctor to reduce the frequency of loose stools.

Over-the-counter electrolyte replacement solutions (e.g., Pedialyte® or Hydralyte®) help replace lost fluids and minerals. These can be sipped regularly to maintain electrolyte balance and are safer than plain water alone for severe diarrhea​:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}.

Imodium Multi-Symptom (loperamide + simethicone) is an option if you have diarrhea with a lot of gas or cramps. The simethicone helps relieve gas discomfort while loperamide addresses the diarrhea (follow dosing instructions on the label).

Probiotic supplements (such as Lactobacillus GG or Saccharomyces boulardii) may help shorten the duration of diarrhea by restoring gut flora. Consult your oncology team before using probiotics, but consuming yogurt with live cultures is a safe way to get probiotics​:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}.

If diarrhea is mild, you could use bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol®) to reduce intestinal inflammation and fluid secretion. However, always check with your doctor before using bismuth, and do not use it long-term (it can cause black tongue/stools and isn’t advised if you have low platelet counts)​:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}.

homeRemedies: Maintain meticulous oral hygiene with gentle tools. Use a very soft toothbrush or foam swabs to clean your teeth and mouth after meals​:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}. Rinse your mouth multiple times a day with a bland solution (for example, 1/2 teaspoon baking soda and 1/4 teaspoon salt in 1 cup of warm water) to keep the mouth clean and neutralize acids​:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}.

Avoid mouthwashes that contain alcohol and avoid tobacco use​:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}​:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}. Alcohol can dry and irritate mouth tissues, worsening sores. Instead, use alcohol-free mouthwash or plain saline/baking soda rinses which soothe and hydrate the mouth​:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}.

Keep the mouth and lips moist. Drink water frequently and suck on ice chips or popsicles to numb pain and hydrate tissues​:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}. Apply lip balm often to prevent cracked lips​:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}. Staying well-hydrated (aim for 2–3 liters of fluids daily if allowed) helps your oral tissues heal​:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}.

Eat a soft, bland diet that avoids irritating your mouth. Choose foods that are soft or pureed (scrambled eggs, smoothies, mashed potatoes, yogurt, milkshakes, soup) and prefer cool or room-temperature foods which may be soothing​:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}​:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}. Avoid rough, crunchy foods and acidic or spicy foods (citrus, tomato sauce, chili, etc.) that can sting or worsen mouth sores​:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}​:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}.

Consider natural remedies for healing: One example is honey – clinical observations suggest that using medical-grade honey (swishing and swallowing or applying to sores) might reduce mouth sore inflammation and promote healing​:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}. If you try this, use a teaspoon of honey and coat the mouth, then avoid eating or drinking for 30 minutes. (Always discuss with your care team before using any non-standard remedy.)
otcOptions: Baking soda paste or protective coating solutions: You can make a soothing paste from baking soda and a little water and gently apply it to mouth sores​:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}. Additionally, an OTC liquid antacid (like Maalox® or Milk of Magnesia) can be dabbed on sores with a cotton swab to coat them and neutralize acids​:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}. These create a protective film over ulcers, easing pain during eating.

Over-the-counter oral anesthetic gels or rinses (e.g., benzocaine products such as Orabase® paste or Anbesol® gel) can numb the sores temporarily​:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}. For example, applying Orabase (a protective paste with benzocaine) before meals can allow you to eat with less pain​:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}. Use these as directed and be cautious because a numb mouth may make you unaware of biting your tongue or cheeks.

Saliva substitutes and moisturizing mouth sprays (Biotène® products or similar) can help with dryness and discomfort in the mouth. These OTC products coat the mouth to relieve dryness, which often accompanies mouth sores, making the environment more comfortable for healing.

Pain relief with systemic medications: If mouth pain is severe, you can use an over-the-counter pain reliever like acetaminophen to reduce overall pain so that you can eat and drink​:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}. (Avoid NSAIDs like ibuprofen if your platelets are low or if your doctor advises against them.) Always follow dosing instructions and check with your provider if you need to use these regularly.

Ice pops or ice chips can serve as an OTC “therapy” – sucking on ice chips during certain chemotherapy infusions has been shown to prevent mouth sores (by constricting blood vessels in the mouth). Even outside of infusions, allowing ice chips to slowly melt in your mouth can numb pain and reduce inflammation in oral tissues (this is sometimes called oral cryotherapy).

homeRemedies: Engage in gentle exercise regularly to improve circulation and nerve health​:contentReference[oaicite:53]{index=53}. Activities like walking, stretching, yoga, or swimming can increase blood flow to hands and feet and have been found to ease tingling and numbness in some patients​:contentReference[oaicite:54]{index=54}. Exercise also helps maintain muscle strength and coordination, which can counteract some effects of neuropathy.

Protect your hands and feet from extreme temperatures and injury. For example, use pot holders/gloves when handling hot items, wear warm gloves and socks in cold weather (cold can worsen numbness), and always wear shoes (even indoors) to prevent cuts or falls since you may not feel injuries as readily. Keeping extremities warm (but not hot) can improve comfort.

Consider complementary therapies such as acupuncture or reflexology​:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}. Some studies and patient reports suggest acupuncture can relieve chemotherapy-induced neuropathy symptoms and pain​:contentReference[oaicite:56]{index=56}. If you pursue this, go to a licensed practitioner and ensure your oncology team is aware. Massage therapy may also help by relieving muscle tension and improving circulation​:contentReference[oaicite:57]{index=57}.

Use relaxation and mind-body techniques to cope with neuropathy discomfort​:contentReference[oaicite:58]{index=58}. Stress and anxiety can heighten the perception of pain. Practices like meditation, guided imagery, or progressive muscle relaxation can reduce stress and potentially lessen the intensity of neuropathic pain​:contentReference[oaicite:59]{index=59}. Even simple mindful breathing exercises can help distract from tingling or burning sensations.

Soothe hands and feet with warm (not hot) water soaks and gentle massage. A lukewarm foot soak or bath can relax muscles and may temporarily ease nerve pain. After soaking, gently massaging the feet and hands with lotion can improve blood flow and provide relief​:contentReference[oaicite:60]{index=60}. (Avoid very hot water to prevent burns, since feeling is reduced.) Ensure you dry your skin well and moisturize to keep skin integrity, as neuropathy can also lead to dry skin or cracks.
otcOptions: Ensure adequate nutritional support for nerve health. If you have any vitamin deficiencies, your doctor may suggest supplements – for example, vitamin B6 or B12 supplementation if levels are low (these B vitamins support nerve function)​:contentReference[oaicite:61]{index=61}. Always consult your healthcare provider before starting vitamins, as excessive B6 can itself cause neuropathy if taken in very high doses.

Topical analgesics can provide relief for localized neuropathy pain. Capsaicin cream (made from chili pepper extract) is available OTC and may reduce pain signaling in nerves with regular use. Applying a pea-sized amount to painful areas a few times daily can, after an initial burning sensation, lead to diminished pain over time. Similarly, lidocaine 4% patches or gel (available OTC) can numb the area and are useful for targeting specific spots of nerve pain​:contentReference[oaicite:62]{index=62}.

Over-the-counter pain relievers can be used for general neuropathy discomfort. Acetaminophen (Tylenol®) or NSAIDs like ibuprofen (Advil®) can help with mild to moderate neuropathic pain or aches​:contentReference[oaicite:63]{index=63}​:contentReference[oaicite:64]{index=64}. They may not eliminate nerve pain completely (since nerve pain can be resistant), but they can ease related pain from muscle soreness or improve overall comfort. (Check with your doctor about NSAID use during chemotherapy.)

Apply lotions or creams containing soothing ingredients like menthol or camphor to numb and cool the nerves. Many OTC neuropathy creams or sports gels (for example, those with menthol, or products like Biofreeze®) create a cooling sensation that can temporarily override pain signals​:contentReference[oaicite:65]{index=65}. Massaging such a lotion into hands and feet can provide short-term relief for burning or tingling sensations.

Dietary supplements that have shown promise in research: Omega-3 fatty acids (fish oil) and L-glutamine are two supplements found in some studies to possibly reduce chemotherapy-induced neuropathy symptoms​:contentReference[oaicite:66]{index=66}. Omega-3s may protect nerves and reduce inflammation, and glutamine might support nerve metabolism. While these are available OTC, you should discuss with your oncologist before starting them to ensure they are safe and appropriate in your situation.

homeRemedies: Incorporate light daily exercise to fight fatigue​:contentReference[oaicite:67]{index=67}. It may seem counterintuitive, but gentle physical activity (like short walks, stretching, or yoga) can boost energy levels and reduce cancer-related fatigue​:contentReference[oaicite:68]{index=68}. Patients who stay mildly active often report less severe fatigue and better overall function.

Balance activity with rest: use energy conservation techniques. Plan your day to do important tasks when you tend to have more energy​:contentReference[oaicite:69]{index=69}, and allow yourself to rest before you become overly exhausted. Taking short naps (15–30 minutes) or relaxation breaks can refresh you​:contentReference[oaicite:70]{index=70}, but avoid very long naps late in the day that might disrupt nighttime sleep​:contentReference[oaicite:71]{index=71}.

Maintain good sleep hygiene and a regular sleep schedule. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time each day​:contentReference[oaicite:72]{index=72}. Create a relaxing bedtime routine (such as a warm shower, listening to calming music, or reading) and avoid screen time for an hour before bed​:contentReference[oaicite:73]{index=73}. Getting a consistent 7–8 hours of sleep per night (if possible) will help combat day-time fatigue​:contentReference[oaicite:74]{index=74}.

Eat a balanced, nutritious diet and stay hydrated​:contentReference[oaicite:75]{index=75}. Fatigue can worsen if you’re not getting enough calories or nutrients. Emphasize protein-rich foods (lean meats, beans, eggs) and plenty of fruits and vegetables to ensure you have necessary vitamins​:contentReference[oaicite:76]{index=76}. Drinking enough fluids is also key – even mild dehydration can cause you to feel more tired​:contentReference[oaicite:77]{index=77}.

Reduce stress and seek support for emotional concerns, as these can contribute to fatigue​:contentReference[oaicite:78]{index=78}. Engage in relaxation techniques like meditation, deep breathing, or gentle Tai Chi to lower stress levels​:contentReference[oaicite:79]{index=79}. It may also help to talk with a counselor or join a support group; mental and emotional strain can make fatigue worse, so addressing anxiety or depression may boost your energy.
otcOptions: American ginseng (Panax quinquefolius) is an herbal supplement that has evidence for improving cancer-related fatigue. In a large clinical trial, 2,000 mg of American ginseng daily significantly reduced fatigue in patients over an 8-week period with minimal side effects​:contentReference[oaicite:80]{index=80}. Ginseng can be purchased OTC in capsule form; discuss with your doctor before starting it to ensure it won’t interfere with your treatment.

A daily multivitamin or specific vitamin supplements might be recommended if you have deficiencies that contribute to fatigue. For instance, if your iron levels or vitamin B12 are low (which can cause anemia and tiredness), your medical team may suggest iron tablets or B12 supplements​:contentReference[oaicite:81]{index=81}. Only take these if indicated by bloodwork and your doctor’s advice – correcting a deficiency can markedly improve energy, but excess supplementation is not helpful.

Ensure adequate caloric and protein intake on days you feel too fatigued to eat full meals. Nutritional drinks or shakes (like Ensure®, Boost®) are OTC options that provide protein, calories, and vitamins and can serve as a meal substitute or snack to keep your energy up. Likewise, electrolyte beverages (sports drinks) can help if you’re dehydrated or low on electrolytes from not eating/drinking enough​:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82}.

Caffeine in moderation can be used as a mild stimulant to combat fatigue. A morning cup of coffee or green tea, for example, may help you feel more alert and improve concentration. Keep intake moderate (for instance, 1–2 cups of coffee) and avoid caffeine after early afternoon so it doesn’t disrupt sleep. If you have heart palpitations or anxiety, consult your doctor about caffeine use.

Vitamin D supplements: If you are deficient in vitamin D, supplementation can improve muscle function and energy levels. Many cancer patients have low vitamin D, and an OTC vitamin D3 supplement (commonly 1,000–2,000 IU daily) may be advised by your provider to reach optimal levels, potentially improving fatigue. Always confirm with a blood test and medical advice before supplementing.

homeRemedies: Bathe with lukewarm (not hot) water and limit bath/shower time​:contentReference[oaicite:83]{index=83}. Hot water can strip natural oils from your skin and worsen dryness. Use a gentle, fragrance-free soap or cleanser (for example, a mild moisturizing soap like Dove® or Cetaphil®) to avoid irritation​:contentReference[oaicite:84]{index=84}. Gently pat your skin dry with a soft towel instead of rubbing vigorously​:contentReference[oaicite:85]{index=85}.

Moisturize immediately after washing. While your skin is still slightly damp, apply a thick moisturizer to lock in moisture​:contentReference[oaicite:86]{index=86}. This helps trap water in the skin. You can also add a few drops of baby oil or bath oil to your bath water, or smooth it on wet skin right after bathing, to seal in hydration​:contentReference[oaicite:87]{index=87}.

Stay well-hydrated by drinking fluids throughout the day​:contentReference[oaicite:88]{index=88}. Hydrating from the inside can improve the moisture content of your skin. Aim for about 2 liters of water or non-caffeinated beverages daily (or as advised by your provider, especially if you have fluid restrictions). Also, using a humidifier in your home, particularly in your bedroom at night, can add moisture to the air and prevent your skin from drying out.

Wear soft, breathable fabrics next to your skin (cotton is ideal)​:contentReference[oaicite:89]{index=89}. Avoid scratchy wool or harsh synthetics touching your skin, as they can aggravate dryness and itching. Wash clothes in mild, fragrance-free detergent to avoid residue that can irritate your skin​:contentReference[oaicite:90]{index=90}.

Protect your skin from harsh weather. In cold, windy weather, cover up with gloves and scarves to shield your skin from chapping​:contentReference[oaicite:91]{index=91}. In sunny weather, use a broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher) on exposed skin to prevent sunburn, as chemotherapy can make skin more sensitive to sun​:contentReference[oaicite:92]{index=92}. Sunburn will further dry and damage skin, so prevention is key.
otcOptions: Heavy moisturizers and skin creams: Use a rich emollient cream or ointment (rather than a light lotion) to combat chemo-related dry skin. Products like Eucerin®, Aquaphor®, CeraVe® cream, or those containing hyaluronic acid, glycerin, or ceramides are effective. Apply liberally at least twice a day​:contentReference[oaicite:93]{index=93}. These moisturizers create a barrier that prevents water loss from the skin and attract water into the outer skin layers​:contentReference[oaicite:94]{index=94}.

Colloidal oatmeal baths or lotions (e.g., Aveeno®) can soothe itching and dryness. Oatmeal has anti-inflammatory properties and is gentle on sensitive skin. You can add an oatmeal bath packet to lukewarm bath water, or apply an oatmeal-based cream to itchy spots to relieve discomfort and moisturize (these products are readily available OTC).

1% hydrocortisone cream is an over-the-counter steroid cream that can be applied to small, itchy areas of dry skin to reduce redness and inflammation. If your skin is extremely itchy or has rash-like patches, using hydrocortisone once or twice a day for a few days can help calm it down. (Do not use on large areas or for more than a week or two without consulting a doctor.)

Unscented, gentle laundry detergents and soaps: OTC products labeled “free & clear” (like All Free Clear® detergent) or those made for babies are good choices to prevent chemical irritation. Also consider soap substitutes like cleansing creams or body washes for sensitive skin that add moisture (some brands: Vanicream™ cleanser, Neutrogena® Ultra Gentle). These help clean without stripping natural oils​:contentReference[oaicite:95]{index=95}.

Sun protection products: A broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher) and a moisturizing lip balm with SPF are important OTC items for dry, sensitive skin. Chemotherapy can make your skin more prone to sun damage. Using sunscreen daily prevents UV rays from further drying out or burning your skin. Choose a sunscreen formulated for sensitive skin (mineral sunscreens with zinc or titanium dioxide tend to be less irritating). Apply before going outdoors and reapply every 2 hours if staying outside.

homeRemedies: Practice consistent sleep hygiene. Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day, even on weekends​:contentReference[oaicite:96]{index=96}. Keeping a regular schedule helps regulate your body’s internal clock. Establish a relaxing pre-sleep routine – for example, dim the lights, take a warm bath, listen to calming music or do gentle stretches before bed​:contentReference[oaicite:97]{index=97}. This signals your body that it’s time to wind down.

Make sure your sleeping environment is conducive to rest. Keep your bedroom dark, quiet, and cool (around 65°F if comfortable)​:contentReference[oaicite:98]{index=98}. Use earplugs or a white noise machine to block noises if needed, and consider blackout curtains or an eye mask to eliminate light. Reserve the bed for sleep and intimacy only – try not to read, watch TV, or use your phone in bed​:contentReference[oaicite:99]{index=99}, so your brain associates the bed only with sleeping.

Avoid stimulants and heavy meals in the hours before bedtime. Cut off caffeine (coffee, black tea, colas, etc.) by early afternoon​:contentReference[oaicite:100]{index=100}, since it can linger in your system and interfere with sleep. Avoid alcohol at night as well – while it might make you drowsy, it disrupts sleep cycles and can cause you to wake up more. Finish dinner at least 2–3 hours before bed and keep late-night snacks light and bland (a piece of toast or a glass of warm milk)​:contentReference[oaicite:101]{index=101}.

Use relaxation techniques to manage stress or racing thoughts that interfere with sleep​:contentReference[oaicite:102]{index=102}. Try deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, meditation, or guided imagery when you get into bed​:contentReference[oaicite:103]{index=103}. For example, you can inhale slowly for 4 seconds, exhale for 6 seconds, focusing on the breath. Alternatively, visualize a peaceful scene (like being on a calm beach) to take your mind off worries. Some people find listening to a sleep meditation or nature sounds helpful.

If you can’t fall asleep within ~20 minutes or you wake up and can’t drift back to sleep, get out of bed and do a quiet activity in low light​:contentReference[oaicite:104]{index=104}. For instance, go to another room and read a dull book or listen to soft music. Avoid bright screens. Return to bed only when you feel sleepy again. This prevents you from tossing and turning anxiously. Also, limiting daytime naps to no more than 30 minutes and not too late in the day will help ensure you’re sleepy at night​:contentReference[oaicite:105]{index=105}.
otcOptions: Melatonin supplement – a synthetic form of the hormone your body uses to regulate sleep. Taking an OTC melatonin pill (~3 mg to 5 mg) about 30-60 minutes before bedtime can help induce sleep, especially if your sleep cycle has been disrupted​:contentReference[oaicite:106]{index=106}. Melatonin is generally safe and causes less morning drowsiness than typical sleep medications. (It’s wise to discuss the appropriate dose with your doctor.)

Over-the-counter sleep aids containing antihistamines can be used occasionally for short-term insomnia. Examples include diphenhydramine (the ingredient in Benadryl® and ZzzQuil®) and doxylamine (Unisom®)​:contentReference[oaicite:107]{index=107}. These can make you drowsy and help you fall asleep, but be aware they can cause grogginess the next day and, with regular use, may lose effectiveness. Use them sparingly and follow the product instructions. If you are an older adult, use caution as these can cause confusion or dizziness in some people​:contentReference[oaicite:108]{index=108}.

Herbal supplements for sleep: Some people try valerian root, chamomile, or passionflower, which are available in teas or pill form. Valerian (often taken ~400-600 mg at bedtime) has mild sedative effects for some individuals, and chamomile tea before bed is a popular remedy for relaxation. Evidence for their effectiveness is mixed, but they are low-risk. Ensure your healthcare team knows about any herbs you take, as even natural supplements can interact with medications.

Magnesium supplements or Epsom salt baths: Magnesium is a mineral that can promote muscle relaxation and healthy sleep. An Epsom salt (magnesium sulfate) bath in warm water in the evening can relax muscles and calm the mind, potentially improving sleep onset. Alternatively, if your magnesium level is low, a magnesium glycinate supplement at night might help (consult your doctor for the appropriate dose). Do not exceed recommended doses, as too much magnesium can cause side effects.

If pain or discomfort is keeping you awake, using appropriate OTC remedies can indirectly improve sleep. For example, if you have mild pain, a dose of acetaminophen or ibuprofen in the evening (if approved by your doctor) can reduce pain enough to let you fall asleep more easily. Similarly, treating heartburn with an OTC antacid or acid reducer, or using an anti-nausea remedy if you feel queasy, can remove those barriers to sleep. Always address the root cause of insomnia symptoms with the appropriate OTC aid.
